content.text:
# Draft:Tabbing (Tactical Advance to Battle)

----
Tabbing is a British Army term, from the UK's Parachute Regiment and airborne forces, meaning tactical-advance-to-battle. It is a loaded march, requiring moving at speed (in combat boots), carrying a weighted bergen (a UK army term for 'backpack'), across undulating terrain.
In training, distances are typically up to 16 km (10 miles) carrying 35-40 lbs (15 kg) The infamous "Ten Miler" is an integral part of the P Company selection course for The Parachute Regiment. The UK's Royal Marines conduct a 9 mile Tab as part of their selection.
Tabs can also be conducted to commemorate historical events or for charity - often linked to those that support the airborne forces. In the UK, a popular charity event - open to the public - is the PARA'S 10 - run by [https://supportourparas.org/ Support Our Paras] (The Parachute Regiment and Airborne Forces charity)- a ten mile endurance race along military lines, open to all comers. There are both weighted - tabbing - and unweighted categories.
Tabbing is normally conducted carrying a military backpack. Army surplus, such as the British Army PLCE rucksack or United States ALICE field pack, are popular amongst civilians.
